discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
"The itsi_grouped_alerts index is the index that contains live episode data. Each time a correlation search runs and updates an episode, itsi_grouped_alerts houses a new entry for the episode. It is this index you will search over to look for open episodes attached to your service."
source: https://lantern.splunk.com/Observability/Product_Tips/IT_Service_Intelligence/Bringing_episode_data_into_service_scores

Selected Answer: C
"Each service has a default seep dive that initially shows all of that service's own KPIs."
C. It initially shows all of the KPIs for a selected service.

choices.B: It initially shows the highest importance KPIs.
choices.C: It initially shows all of the KPIs for a selected service.
choices.A: It initially shows the health scores for all services.
choices.D: It initially shows all the entity swim lanes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes a default deep dive?

choices.A: Configure –> Policies –> Smart Mode –> Enable, select “fields”, click “Save”
choices.B: Enable grouping in Notable Event Review, select “Smart Mode”, select “fields”, and click “Save”
choices.C: Edit the aggregation policy, enable smart mode, select fields to analyze, click “Save”
choices.D: Edit the notable event view, enable smart mode, select “fields”, and click “Save”

questions.question_text: Which of the following describes enabling smart mode for an aggregation policy?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C - Edit the aggregation policy, enable smart mode, select fields to analyze, click “Save”
C. Edit the aggregation policy, enable smart mode, select fields to analyze, click “Save”

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

choices.D: KPI total values are aggregated from multiple different category values in the source events.
choices.A: Automatically associate entities to services using multiple entity aliases.
choices.B: All of the entities have the same identifying field name.
choices.C: Being able to split a CPU usage KPI by host name.
